spanishExample: ¡Dale uno de esos!
englishTranslation: Give him one of those!

spanishExample: ¡Dame una mano con esto, por favor!
englishTranslation: Give me a hand with this, please!
vocabIncluded: darle una mano a: "give a hand to" (idiom)

spanishExample: ¿Cuáles de los *projects* están en manos de Juan?
englishTranslation: Which of the projects are in Juan’s hands?
vocabIncluded: en manos de alguien: "in someone's hands" (idiom)

spanishExample: ¿Me puedes dar una mano con esto?
englishTranslation: Can you give me a hand with this?
vocabIncluded: darle una mano a: "give a hand to" (idiom)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Dale más de eso porque es bueno para el cuerpo.
englishTranslation: Give him more of that because it’s good for his body.

spanishExample: Dile a tu hijo que *remove* las manos de la boca.
englishTranslation: Tell your son to remove his hands from his mouth.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica

spanishExample: El problema está en las manos *of the committee,* se lo dimos a ellas.
englishTranslation: The problem is in the hands of the committee, we gave it to them(f).
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
ella: "them" after a preposition (fem. prep. pronoun)
en manos de alguien: "in someone's hands" (idiom)

spanishExample: Él quiere que le dé mi corazón.
englishTranslation: He wants me to give her my heart.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Entonces ahora quiero que se lo des a ellos.
englishTranslation: So now I want you to give it to them(m).
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
"se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"

spanishExample: Está *using* la mente para darle ayuda a su querido papá.
englishTranslation: She is using her mind to give help to her dear dad.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive

spanishExample: Le dará eso a su mamá, quien es un ser querido.
englishTranslation: He will give that to his mom, who is a loved one.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
dará: "will give", "he/she/it will give" (Dar, future, 3rd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Le daré a mi hija *a bow* para la cabeza.
englishTranslation: I’ll give my daughter a bow for her head.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
daré: "will give", "I will give" (Dar, future, 1st person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Lo está dando todo con todo su ser.
englishTranslation: He’s giving it everything with all his being.

spanishExample: Me ha dado *sunglasses* para los ojos.
englishTranslation: She has given me sunglasses for my eyes.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Mi amigo le dio su corazón a su esposa.
englishTranslation: My friend gave his heart to his wife.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Mi querido hermano tiene algo en la cara.
englishTranslation: My dear brother has something on his face.

spanishExample: Muchos dicen que no *you should breathe* por la boca.
englishTranslation: Many say that you shouldn’t breathe through your mouth.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
por to mean “vía/by”, as in "by phone”

spanishExample: No quiere que le demos nada para la cara.
englishTranslation: She doesn’t want us to give her anything for her face.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: No tienes que darle ese, ya tiene muchos.
englishTranslation: You don’t have to give him that one(m), he already has many.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: Quiero a mi familia con todo mi ser.
englishTranslation: I love my family with all my being.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica

spanishExample: Quiero que den una vuelta *holding* las manos.
englishTranslation: I want them to go for a walk holding hands.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Se *he hurt* la cabeza, pero me da lo mismo.
englishTranslation: He hurt his head, but it’s all the same to me.
vocabIncluded: me da lo mismo: "it's all the same to me" (idiom)

spanishExample: Si no le das sangre, podría *die.*
englishTranslation: If you don’t give him blood, he could die.
vocabIncluded: le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
podría: "would be able", "he/she/it would be able" (Poder, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Sus hijos e hijas son sus seres queridos más *close.*
englishTranslation: His sons and daughters are his closest loved ones.
vocabIncluded: e: "and" (synonym for "y", used before a word starting with an "i" sound)

spanishExample: Te damos de vuelta lo que nos diste.
englishTranslation: We’re giving you back what you gave us.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Te dan su sangre.
englishTranslation: They are giving you their blood.
vocabIncluded: te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Te di *good advice* antes.
englishTranslation: I gave you good advice before.
vocabIncluded: te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Tienes que *donate* sangre u otra cosa.
englishTranslation: You have to donate blood or another thing.
vocabIncluded: u: "or" (synonym for "o", used before a word starting with an "o" sound)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Voy a *close* los ojos para *clear* la mente.
englishTranslation: I’m going to close my eyes to clear my mind.
vocabIncluded: para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Voy a *take care of* mi cuerpo mientras esté en ese lugar.
englishTranslation: I’m going to take care of my body as long as I’m at that place.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
